newsitem.title: USA: Lawmakers propose U.S. fund to promote clean power.
newsitem.headline: Lawmakers propose U.S. fund to promote clean power.

text.p: Two House Democrats introduced a bill Thursday to create a U.S. fund to bolster state and local programs promoting renewable energy for electricity, energy conservation, and universal service.

The bill, which assumed states would open local power markets to competition, would impose a transmission fee on energy suppliers to collect up to $6 billion a year to provide matching grants for local energy programs.

"My bill provides a stable funding source to not only help maintain existing energy conservation, renewable energy and low income energy assistance programs, but to expand them around the nation," said Peter DeFazio of Oregon, one of the bill's lead sponsors.

Environmental and consumer advocates are pushing for a transmission fee to ensure universal service and to back renewable energy programs in any legislation that would require states to break up electric utility monopolies, which currently pay for those types of programs.
Energy Department officials have said they are considering a similar proposal for a broad electric restructuring plan.
